choices.text: Fastigial nuclei, Embolifom nuclei, Globose nuclei, Dentate nuclei
Fastigial nuclei, Globose nuclei, Embolifom nuclei, Dentate nuclei
Dentate nuclei, Embolifom nuclei, Globose nuclei, Fastigial nuclei
Dentate nuclei, Globose nuclei, Embolifom nuclei, Fastigial nuclei

questions.text: Which of the following sequence of deep cerebellar nuclei is correct arrangement from medial to lateral side?
questions.solution:
Deep Cerebellar Nuclei

  • Medullary Core: Contains the four deep cerebellar nuclei, crucial for cerebellar function.
  • Nuclei Description:
    • Fastigial Nucleus: Medial and adjacent to the fourth ventricle, involved in balance and posture.
    • Globose Nucleus: Located laterally to the fastigial nucleus; part of the caudomedial group.
    • Emboliform Nucleus: Medial to the dentate nucleus; part of the rostrolateral group.
    • Dentate Nucleus: Lateralmost and largest, responsible for planning and timing of movements.
  • Interconnected Groups:
    • Caudomedial Group: Comprises the fastigial and globose nuclei.
    • Rostrolateral Group: Consists of the emboliform and dentate nuclei.

Key takeaways : mnemonic : lateral to medial cerebellar nuclei

DEGF : Dentate nuclei, Embolifom nuclei, Globose nuclei, Fastigial nuclei

questions.text: Paleocerebellum consists of all of the followings part of cerebellum, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Cerebellar Divisions:

1)Archicerebellum (Vestibular Cerebellum)

  • Phylogeny: Oldest part of the cerebellum, present in fish and lower amphibians.
  • Components: Comprises the flocculonodular lobe and lingula.
  • Function: Primarily vestibular connections, responsible for maintaining equilibrium, muscle tone, and posture of trunk muscles.

2)Paleocerebellum (Spinal Cerebellum)

  • Phylogeny: Developed in terrestrial vertebrates (reptiles and birds) with limb evolution.
  • Components: Includes the anterior lobe (excluding the lingula) and the pyramid and uvula of the inferior vermis.
  • Function: Primarily spinocerebellar connections, involved in limb tone, posture, and crude movements.

3)Neocerebellum (Cerebral Cerebellum)

  • Phylogeny: Most recent part of the cerebellum, developed alongside the telencephalon and cerebral cortex in primates.
  • Components: Comprises the middle lobe, the largest part of the cerebellum, excluding the pyramid and uvula of the inferior vermis.
  • Function: Chiefly corticoponto-cerebellar connections, crucial for smooth execution of skilled voluntary movements.

Key takeaways :

questions.text: All of the following symptoms appears in case of involvement of neocerebellum, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Astereognosis is associated with lesion in parietal lobe.

Cerebellar Syndrome

Cerebellar syndrome arises from lesions due to trauma, vascular occlusion, tumors, etc., resulting in various signs and symptoms based on the affected cerebellar part.

Signs and Symptoms

  1. Archicerebellum Involvement:
    • Truncal Ataxia: Unsteady stance and staggering gait, with a wide base and side-to-side swaying.
    • Nystagmus: Involuntary oscillatory eye movements when looking sideways.
    • Romberg's Sign: Inability to maintain balance when eyes are closed, leading to falls.
  2. Paleocerebellum Involvement:
    • Hypotonia: Diminished muscle tone in limb muscles, leading to unstable joints (flail joints).
    • Pendular Knee Jerk: Oscillating leg movements upon patellar tendon tapping.
    • Ataxia: Inability to maintain balance while walking.
  3. Neocerebellum Involvement:
    • Asynergia: Muscular incoordination.
      • Dysmetria: Inability to gauge distance (past-pointing), tested via the finger-nose test.
      • Intention Tremors: Tremors during purposeful movements, absent at rest.
      • Dysdiadochokinesis: Difficulty performing rapid alternating movements (e.g., pronation/supination).
      • Dysarthria: Slurred and prolonged speech with inappropriate pauses.
      • Rebound Phenomenon: Inability to check the action of agonist muscles, leading to uncontrolled movements when resistance is removed.

Key takeaways : Cerebellar syndrome involves truncal ataxia, staggering gait, and nystagmus with archicerebellum lesions; hypotonia, flail joints, and pendular knee jerk with paleocerebellum lesions; and asynergia, dysmetria, intention tremors, and dysarthria with neocerebellum lesions.

questions.text: All of the following structures form floor of third ventricle of diencephalon, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Boundaries of third ventricle:

  • Anterior Wall:
    • Lamina terminalis
    • Anterior commissure
    • Anterior columns of fornix
  • Posterior Wall
    • Pineal body
    • Posterior commissure
    • Cerebral aqueduct
  • Roof
    • It is formed by body of fornix and the ependyma lining the under surface of the tela choroidea of the third ventricle. The choroid plexus of the third ventricle projects downwards from the roof.
    • At the junction of the roof with the anterior and lateral walls, there are the interventricular foramina.
  • Floor: It is formed by hypothalamic structures:
    • Optic chiasma
    • Tubercinerium
    • Infundibulum (pituitary stalk)
    • Mammillary bodies
    • Posterior perforated substance
    • Tegmentum of the midbrain.
  • Lateral Wall
    • Medial surface of thalamus
    • Hypothalamus
    • The hypothalamic sulcus (separates the thalamus from the hypothalamus).

Key takeaways : Boundaries of third ventricle:

choices.text: Internal carotid artery and posterior cerebral artery
Internal carotid artery and anterior cerebral artery
Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery
Middle cerebral artery and anterior cerebral artery

questions.text: Choroid plexus of lateral ventricle is derived from which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Choroid plexus formation: The choroid plexus in the lateral ventricles is primarily vascularized by branches from the internal carotid artery and the posterior cerebral artery.

Choroid Plexus (Lateral Ventricle):

  • Location: The choroid plexus occupies the floor of the lateral ventricle, extending into the inferior horn via the choroid fissure, situated between the fimbria (below) and the stria terminalis and tail of the caudate nucleus (above).
  • Medial Wall: Along the medial aspect of the cerebral hemisphere, the medial wall of the central part and inferior horn of the lateral ventricle consists only of ependyma.
  • Formation of Choroid Plexus: The pia mater covering the ependyma is invaginated by fringelike tufts of blood vessels, forming the choroid plexus within the central part and inferior horn of the lateral ventricle.
  • Choroid Fissure: The line of invagination where the choroid plexus extends into the lateral ventricle is known as the choroid fissure.
  • Interventricular Foramina: At the interventricular foramina, the choroid plexus from one lateral ventricle is continuous with that of the other lateral ventricle across the third ventricle, allowing for the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) between the ventricles.

Key takeaways : The choroid plexus of lateral ventricle is derived from anterior choroidal artery, a branch of internal carotid artery and the posterior choroidal artery a branch of posterior cerebral artery

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
Given diagram is showing floor of fourth ventricle

Dorsal Aspect of the Medulla Oblongata:

  • Dorsal Median Sulcus: Divides the floor of the medulla into two symmetrical halves.
  • Sulcus Limitans: Divides each half into:
    • Median Eminence: Wider above and narrower below.
      • Presents the Facial Colliculus (opposite the superior fovea) where the genu of the facial nerve loops around the abducent nucleus.
    • Lateral Vestibular Area: Located lateral to the inferior fovea, overlying the vestibular nuclei.
  • Foveae:
    • Superior Fovea: Depression at the cranial end of the sulcus limitans.
    • Inferior Fovea: Depression towards the caudal part.
  • Locus Coeruleus: Found in the uppermost part (pontine part), appears bluish due to pigmented neurons (substantia ferruginea) involved in noradrenaline production, contributing to paradoxical sleep.
  • Triangles:
    • Hypoglossal Triangle: Medial, overlying the hypoglossal nerve nucleus.
    • Vagal Triangle: Lateral, overlying the vagus nerve nucleus.
  • Area Postrema: Small area between the vagal triangle and the gracile tubercle, potentially functioning as a chemoreceptor. Lacks a blood-brain barrier.
  • Funiculus Separans: An ependymal thickening separating the medial eminence and vestibular area.

Key takeaways: The dorsal median sulcus divides the floor into symmetrical halves, with the sulcus limitans separating the median eminence and lateral vestibular area, which includes the facial colliculus, locus coeruleus, hypoglossal and vagal triangles, area postrema, and vestibular area.

questions.text: Anterior nuclei of thalamus is connected to all of the following structures, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The thalamic Nuclei:

  • The thalamic grey matter consists of number of nuclei.
  • The grey matter of the thalamus is traversed anteroposteriorly by a vertical sheet of white fibres, the internal medullary lamina which bifurcates anteriorly to assume a Y-shaped configuration.
  • This Y shaped internal medullary lamina divides the thalamus into three main parts: anterior, medial, and lateral.
  • The anterior part includes the anterior tubercle and lies between the 'limbs' of the Y, the medial and lateral parts lie on either side of the 'stem' of the Y.
  • Each of these parts consists of number of nuclei.

Key takeaways :

questions.text: Mood and emotional balance is associated with which of the following thalamic nuclie?
questions.solution:
Thalamic Nuclei Connections:

  • Ventral Posteromedial Nucleus (VPM):
    • Receives general sensory input from the head and face via the trigeminal lemniscus.
    • Processes taste sensations from taste buds through the solitariothalamic tract.
  • Ventral Posterolateral Nucleus (VPL):
    • Receives exteroceptive sensations (pain, touch, temperature) through the spinal lemniscus.
    • Receives proprioceptive sensations (muscle/joint sense, vibration, two-point discrimination) through the medial lemniscus.
    • Processes sensory information from the body (excluding the face and head).
  • Anterior Nucleus:
    • Important for attention and recent memory; lesions can lead to recent memory loss.
  • Medial Dorsal Nucleus:
    • Associated with mood and emotional balance; influenced by current sensory input and past experiences, affecting feelings of well-being or malaise.

Key takeaways :

questions.text: Which of the following laminae (layers) of lateral geniculate body receives fibres of opposite side retina?
questions.solution:
Lateral geniculate body:

  • Lateral geniculate body is a small ovoid prominence visible at the terminal end of the optic tract.
  • It is situated on the inferior surface of the pulvinar, anterolateral to the medial geniculate body.
  • It is smaller than the medial geniculate body and connected to the superior colliculus by the superior brachium.
  • Structure:
    • The grey matter of lateral geniculate body consists of six layers (or laminae) separated by nerve fibres.
    • These layers are numbered 1 to 6 from ventral to dorsal side.
    • Laminae 1, 4, and 6 receive fibres from the retina of opposite side.
    • Laminae 2, 3, and 5 from the retina of the same side.
  • Connections:
    • Afferents: Lateral root of the optic tract consisting of most of the retinal fibres of both the eyes (temporalm fibres of the same side and nasal fibres of the opposite side).
    • Efferents: Geniculocalcarine fibres project as the optic radiation through retrolentiform part of internal capsule to the visual cortex of the occipital lobe (areas 17, 18, and 19).
  • Functions:
    • The lateral geniculate body is the last relay station on the visual pathway.

Key takeaways :

Laminae 1, 4, and 6 receive fibres from the retina of opposite side.

Laminae 2, 3, and 5 from the retina of the same side.

questions.text: Which of the following nucleus of hypothalamus is considered as "satiety centre"?
questions.solution:
• A. Anterior Nucleus: Involved in attention and recent memory processing.
  • B. Lateral Nucleus: Plays a role in sensory integration and motor functions.
  • D. Dorsomedial Nucleus: Involved in higher cognitive functions, emotional processing, and memory.

Key takeaways: Hypothalamic nuclei and its functions as follow:

questions.text: Hemiballismus is a condition involving which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Discrete lesions of the subthalamic nucleus result in hemiballismus.
  • It is characterised by involuntary choreiform movements on the opposite side of the body.
  • The condition is abolished by ablation of the globus pallidus or of its efferent tracts, the anterior ventral nucleus of the thalamus, area 4 of the cerebral cortex, or of the corticospinal tract.
  • From these facts, it appears that the subthalamic nucleus has an inhibitory control on the globus pallidus and on the cerebral cortex.

Key takeaways :

Lesions of the subthalamic nucleus result in hemiballismus, causing involuntary movements on the opposite side of the body, which can be alleviated by ablating the globus pallidus.

choices.text: Caudate nucleus, putamen and globus pallidus

questions.text: Which of the following structures together known as neostriatum?
questions.solution:
The Corpus Striatum:

  • Components: Comprises the caudate nucleus, putamen, and globus pallidus.
  • Lentiform Complex: The putamen and globus pallidus were historically viewed as a single entity, the lentiform nucleus, due to their proximity.
  • Neostriatum: The putamen and caudate nucleus share similar chemocytoarchitecture and connections, and are collectively known as the neostriatum or striatum.
  • Function:
    • Input Structure: The striatum is the primary input structure of the basal ganglia, receiving most afferent connections.
    • Efferent Connections: It projects primarily to the globus pallidus and pars reticularis of the substantia nigra.
    • Output Structure: The globus pallidus (especially the medial segment) and the pars reticularis are key output structures, sending projections mainly to the thalamus.

Key takeaways : The corpus striatum consists of the caudate nucleus and putamen (together known as the neostriatum), and the globus pallidus, serving as the principal input structure of the basal ganglia with efferent connections primarily to the globus pallidus and thalamus.

questions.text: Amygdala body present in which of the following lobe?
questions.solution:
Amygdaloid body:

  • It is an almond-shaped mass of grey matter in the temporal lobe, lying anterosuperior to the tip of inferior horn of lateral ventricle.
  • It is situated deep to uncus which serves as a surface landmark for its location.
  • Developmentally it is related to basal nuclei but functionally it is included in the limbic system and therefore shares its functions.
  • The amygdala (amygdaloid nuclear complex) consists of lateral, central and basal nuclei lying in the dorsomedial temporal pole, anterior to the hippocampus, close to the tail of the caudate nucleus and partly deep to the gyrus semilunaris, gyrus ambiens and uncinate gyrus.
  • Collectively, the nuclei form the ventral, superior and medial walls of the tip of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle.
  • The amygdala is partly continuous above with the inferomedial margin of the claustrum.
  • Fibres of the external capsule and substriatal grey matter, including the cholinergic magnocellular nucleus basalis of Meynert, partially separate it from the putamen and globus pallidus. Laterally, the amygdala lies close to the optic tract.

Key takeaways :

The amygdaloid body is an almond-shaped mass of grey matter in the temporal lobe, located deep to the uncus and functionally part of the limbic system, consisting of lateral, central, and basal nuclei near the hippocampus.

questions.text: 14) Which of following is not a part of the hippocampal formation?
questions.solution:
The hippocampal formation: It includes

  • The dentate gyrus
  • Hippocampus proper
  • Subicular complex (subiculum, presubiculum, parasubiculum)
  • Entorhinal cortex (area 28)
  1. Passing medially from the collateral sulcus, the neocortex of the parahippocampal gyrus merges with the transitional juxtallocortex of the subiculum.
  2. The latter curves superomedially to the inferior surface of the dentate gyrus, then laterally to the laminae of the hippocampus.
  3. This curvature continues, first superiorly, then medially above the dentate gyrus, and ends pointing towards the centre of the superior surface of the dentate gyrus.

Key takeaways :

The hippocampal formation consists of the dentate gyrus, hippocampus proper, subicular complex, and entorhinal cortex, with the neocortex of the parahippocampal gyrus merging with the subiculum and curving to connect with the dentate gyrus and hippocampus.

questions.text: Parkinson's disease is characterized by a triad of symptoms, which of the following is not a part of that triad?
questions.solution:
Parkinsonism (Parkinson's Disease/Paralysis Agitans):

  • Age of Onset: Typically occurs after 50 years.
  • Cause: Caused by a deficiency of the neurotransmitter dopamine in the corpus striatum, resulting from lesions in the substantia nigra and/or its projections.
  • Dopamine Function: Synthesized in melanin-containing pigmented cells of the substantia nigra and transported to the corpus striatum via nigrostriatal fibers. Dopamine inhibits activity within the corpus striatum; its deficiency leads to disinhibition and the neurological changes seen in Parkinsonism.

Characteristic Features:

  • Resting Tremors: Slight shaking of hands when at rest, diminishing with movement and worsening with emotional excitation.
  • Muscular Rigidity:
    • Lead-Pipe Rigidity: Uniform resistance throughout the movement.
    • Cogwheel Rigidity: Jerky resistance during movement.
  • Pill-Rolling Movements: Circular movements of the thumb and index fingertips, a specific type of resting tremor.
  • Mask-like Face: Reduced facial expression due to impaired muscle control for emotional expression.
  • Stiff, Shuffling Gait: Resulting from joint rigidity.
  • Stooped Posture: Flexed back, adducted and flexed arms, and bent knees.
  • Slowed Movements: General slowing of movements with a lack of associated movements (e.g., arm swinging while walking).

Key takeaways: Parkinson's disease, typically occurs after age 50 due to dopamine deficiency in the corpus striatum from lesions in the substantia nigra, leading to neurological changes from the loss of inhibitory influences.

questions.text: Posterior inferior cerebellar artery is a branch of:
questions.solution:
Arterial supply of the cerebellum:

  • The cerebellum is supplied by three pairs of cerebellar arteries:
  • Superior cerebellar artery, a branch of basilar artery supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum.
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery, a branch of basilar artery supplies the anterior part of the inferior surface of the cerebellum.
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery, a branch of vertebral artery supplies the posterior part of the inferior surface of the cerebellum.
  • The cerebellar arteries form superficial anastomoses on the cortical surface. Anastomoses between deeper, subcortical, branches have been postulated.

Key takeaways :

Basilar Artery: Formed by the union of the two vertebral arteries.

Internal Carotid Artery: Arises from the common carotid artery.

Middle Cerebral Artery: A branch of the internal carotid artery.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
Above figures are showing the blood supply of cerebrum

  • The entire blood supply of the cerebral cortex comes from cortical branches of the anterior, middle and posterior cerebral arteries.
  • Anterior and midlle cerebral arteries are branches of internal carotid artery.
  • Posterior cerebral artery is a branch of basilar artery.
  • Cerebral cortex is supplied by branches of all three cerebral arteries.
  • Middle cerebral is main artery on superolateral surface.
  • Anterior cerebral artery is chief artery on medial surface.
  • Posterior cerebral is principal artery on inferior surface.

Key takeaways :

choices.text: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature on limbs
Contralateral loss of pain and temperature on trunk

questions.text: PICA syndrome includes all of the following symptoms, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Thrombosis of superior cerebellar artery results in:
    • Cerebellum: Disturbed gait, limb ataxia.
    • Brainstem: Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.
    • Contralateral sensory loss: Pain and temperature (including face).
  • Damage to anterior inferior cerebellar artery results in: AICA syndrome
    • Cerebellum: Ipsilateral limb ataxia.
    • Brainstem: Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.
    • Sensory loss: Pain and temperature of face.
    • Facial weakness and paralysis of lateral gaze.
    • Contralateral sensory loss: Pain and temperature of limbs and trunk.
  • Thrombosis of posterior inferior cerebellar artery results in: PICA syndrome
    • Cerebellum: Dysarthria, ipsilateral limb ataxia, vertigo and nystagmus (due to damage to vestibulofloccular connections).
    • Brainstem: Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.
    • Sensory loss: Pain and temperature of face.
    • Pharyngeal and laryngeal paralysis.
    • Contralateral sensory loss: Pain and temperature of limbs and trunk.

Key takeaways : Thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) leads to dysarthria, ipsilateral limb ataxia, vertigo, nystagmus, Horner's syndrome, facial sensory loss, pharyngeal and laryngeal paralysis, and contralateral sensory loss in limbs and trunk.

choices.text: It is devoid of muscular tissue
It does not follows arterial pattern
It runs mainly in subdural space

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about venous drainage of the brain?
questions.solution:
Venous Drainage of the Brain:

  • Pathway: Veins drain into intracranial dural venous sinuses, leading to the internal jugular veins in the neck.
  • Drainage Process: Veins emerge from the brain, traverse the subarachnoid space, and pierce the arachnoid and meningeal layers of dura mater to enter venous sinuses.

Characteristic Features:

  • Non-Conformity: Venous return does not follow the arterial pattern.
  • Wall Structure: Extremely thin-walled veins due to the absence of muscular tissue.
  • Lack of Valves: Veins possess no valves.
  • Location: Primarily located in the subarachnoid space.
  • Sinus Entry: Cerebral veins enter obliquely into dural venous sinuses, preventing collapse under increased intracranial pressure.

Types of Veins:

  • Cerebral Veins
  • Cerebellar Veins
  • Veins of the Brainstem

This structure and arrangement facilitate efficient venous drainage from the brain while accommodating changes in intracranial pressure.

Key takeaways :

The venous drainage of the brain features non-conforming venous return to arterial patterns, extremely thin-walled and valveless veins primarily located in the subarachnoid space, and oblique entry of cerebral veins into dural venous sinuses to prevent collapse under increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: Identify the marked part of cerebrum:
questions.solution:
Supero-lateral Surface of Cerebrum:

  • Marked Area: Represents part of the inferior frontal gyrus.

Key Features:

  • Prefrontal Sulcus:
    • Often broken into 2 or 3 parts.
    • Runs downwards and forwards, parallel and slightly anterior to the central sulcus.
  • Precentral Gyrus:
    • Area between the central sulcus and precentral sulcus.
  • Frontal Lobe Division:
    • Superior and Inferior Frontal Sulci:
      • Located anterior to the precentral sulcus.
      • Run horizontally and divide the frontal lobe into:
        • Superior Frontal Gyrus
        • Middle Frontal Gyrus
        • Inferior Frontal Gyrus
  • Inferior Frontal Gyrus Parts:
    • Divided by the anterior and ascending rami of the lateral sulcus into three regions:
      • Pars Orbitalis: Below the anterior ramus.
      • Pars Triangularis: Between the anterior and ascending rami.
      • Pars Opercularis: Posterior to the ascending ramus.

In the given figure below the marked structure as follow.

a - Pars orbitalis

b - Pars triangularis

c - Pars opercularis

Key takeaways :

The prefrontal sulcus runs parallel to the central sulcus, with the precentral gyrus between them, while anteriorly, the superior and inferior frontal sulci divide the frontal lobe into gyri, and the lateral sulcus rami further divide the inferior frontal gyrus into pars orbitalis, pars triangularis, and pars opercularis.

questions.text: Paracentral lobule is marked as no?
questions.solution:
• The boundaries of paracentral lobule needs to be elaborated, as it is the cortical (highest) centre of micturition and defecation.
  • The paracentral lobule is bounded above, by the superomedial border of the hemisphere, below by the cingulate sulcus, and posteriorly by the upturned posterior end of the cingulate sulcus. The paracentral lobule is invaded by the downturned upper end of the central sulcus.

Key takeaways :

The paracentral lobule, marked as 2, is crucial for micturition and defecation. Its boundaries include the superomedial border of the hemisphere above, the cingulate sulcus below, and the upturned posterior end of the cingulate sulcus posteriorly. It is also affected by the downturned upper end of the central sulcus.

questions.text: Given figure is showing circle of willis. Identify the marked artery.
questions.solution:
Circle of Willis (circulus arteriosus):

  • The major arteries supplying the cerebrum (i.e. branches of basilar and internal carotid arteries) get interconnected to one another at the base of the brain to form a six-sided polygon of arteries called circulus arteriosus or circle of Willis
  • The circle of Willis is formed around the interpeduncular fossa and lies in the interpeduncular subarachnoid cistern.
  • It contributes most of the arterial blood supply to the brain.

Key takeaways :

  • Circle of Willis is formed:
  • Anteriorly:
    • By the anterior communicating and the anterior cerebral arteries.
  • Posteriorly:
    • By the basilar artery dividing into two posterior cerebral arteries.
  • Laterally on each side:
    • By the posterior communicating artery connecting the internal carotid artery with the posterior cerebral artery.

questions.text: Which of the following correct about parts of corpus callosum from behind forward?
questions.solution:
• The corpus callosum is the largest commissure of the brain connecting the cerebral cortex of the two cerebral hemispheres.
  • Since it connects the neocortex (neopallium) of the two sides, it attains enormous size in man. It is 10 cm long, nearly half of the anteroposterior length of the hemispheres, and consists of about 300 million fibres.
  • Genu:
    • It is thick curved anterior extremity of corpus callosum which lies 4 cm behind the frontal pole.
    • Genu forms the anterior boundary of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle. The fibres of genu sweep (curve) forwards on either side into the anterior parts of the frontal lobes, forming a fork-like structure, the forceps minor.
  • Rostrum:
    • The genu extends downwards and backwards as a thin prolongation the join the lamina terminalis forming, rostrum of corpus callosum.
    • The rostrum forms the floor of the anterior horn of lateral ventricle and its fibres extends inferiorly to connect the orbital surfaces of the two frontal lobes.
  • Trunk:
    • The trunk is main (middle) part of the corpus callosum between its thick anterior (genu) and posterior (splenium) extremities.
    • Its fibres connect most of the frontal and anterior parts of the parietal lobes of the two cerebral hemispheres.
    • The central part of the corpus callosum forms the roof of the central part of the lateral ventricle.
  • Splenium:
    • The splenium is the massive posterior extremity of the corpus callosum, lying 6 cm in front of the occipital pole.
    • It overhangs the thalamic pulvinars, pineal gland and tectum of the midbrain.
    • The transverse fissure containing tela choroidea of third ventricle, posterior choroidal arteries and great cerebral vein of Galen is located inferior to the splenium. 1111

parts of corpus callosum

Key takeaways:

The corpus callosum is divided from before backwards into four parts:

  • Rostrum, Genu, Trunk/body, Splenium

choices.text: Hippocampal formation, anterior nucleus of thalamus, cingulate gyrus, mammillary body, entorhinal cortex, fornix
Hippocampal formation, entorhinal cortex, anterior nucleus of thalamus, mammillary body, cingulate gyrus, fornix
Hippocampal formation, mammillary body, anterior nucleus of thalamus, cingulate gyrus, entorhinal cortex, fornix
Hippocampal formation, cingulate gyrus, anterior nucleus of thalamus, mammillary body, entorhinal cortex, fornix

questions.text: Which of the following correct sequence about the papez circuit ?
questions.solution:
Fornix and Papez Circuit

Fornix:

  • Definition: A large bundle of mainly projection fibers connecting the hippocampus with the mammillary body; contains commissural and association fibers.
  • Function: Sole efferent system of the hippocampus.
  • Location:
    • Medial surface of the cerebral hemisphere.
    • Arched prominent bundle of white fibers beneath the corpus callosum, along the lower border of the septum pellucidum.
  • Structure:
    • One fornix in each hemisphere, closely related/fused beneath the middle of the body of the corpus callosum, usually described as a single structure.

Papez Circuit:

  • Limbic Structures Involved:
    • Hippocampal formation
    • Mammillary body/nucleus
    • Anterior nucleus of thalamus
    • Cingulate gyrus
    • Entorhinal cortex
  • Route of Papez Circuit:
    1. Hippocampal formation →
    2. Mammillary nucleus →
    3. Cingulate gyrus →
    4. Entorhinal cortex →
    5. Hippocampal formation
  • Function: The connections within the Papez circuit create a mechanism for elaborating central emotions and emotional expressions.

Key takeaways :

The Papez circuit comprises the hippocampal formation, mammillary body, anterior nucleus of the thalamus, cingulate gyrus, and entorhinal cortex.

questions.text: Which of the following Brodmann's cortical area is affected in case of tactile agnosia?
questions.solution:
Area 5 and 7 - Sensory association area (tactile agnosia)

  • Other options :
  • Area 39, 40 - Sensory speech wernicke area (receptive sensory aphasia)
  • Area 44, 45 - Motor speech Borca's area (expressive motor aphasia)
  • Area 3, 1 and 2 - Primary sensory area (loss of sensation)

Sensory association area:

  • Sensory association area occupies the superior parietal lobule corresponding to the Areas 5 and 7 of Brodmann.
  • It is concerned with the perception of shape, size, roughness, and texture of the objects.
  • Thus, it enables the individual to recognize the objects placed in his/her hand without seeing. Such ability is referred to as stereognosis.
  • Lesions of this area result in inability to recognize or identify an object by its feel.
  • This condition is called tactile agnosia or astereognosis.

Key takeaways :

The sensory association area in the superior parietal lobule (Brodmann Areas 5 and 7) is responsible for perceiving shape, size, and texture of objects, enabling stereognosis, and lesions here can cause tactile agnosia or astereognosis, impairing object recognition by touch.

questions.text: All of the following structures present in interpeduncular fossa, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Interpeduncular Fossa
  • Definition: A rhomboidal space located between the cerebral peduncles.
  • Boundaries:
    • Laterally: Crus cerebri of the cerebral peduncles.
    • Anteriorly: Optic chiasma and optic tracts.
    • Posteriorly: Pons.
  • Contents:
    • Tuber Cinereum: A raised area of grey matter located anterior to the mammillary bodies.
    • Mammillary Bodies: Two small spherical bodies involved in memory.
    • Infundibulum: A narrow stalk connecting the hypophysis cerebri (pituitary gland) with the tuber cinereum.
    • Posterior Perforated Substance: A layer of grey matter in the angle between the crus cerebri, perforated by branches of the posterior cerebral arteries.
    • Oculomotor Nerve: Emerges dorsomedial to the corresponding crus cerebri.

Key takeaways: The interpeduncular fossa contains tuber cinereum, mammillary bodies, infundibulum, posterior perforated substance, and oculomotor nerve.
